art.definition: Art that does not attempt to represent an accurate depiction of a visual reality but instead uses shapes, colors, forms, and gestural marks to achieve its effect.
A piece of cloth or other material on which a painting is made.
The arrangement of elements in a work of art, including the use of line, shape, color, texture, and space.
A modernist movement, initially in poetry and painting, originating in Germany at the beginning of the 20th century. It sought to express the emotional experience of the modern individual.

A 19th-century art movement that originated with a group of Paris-based artists. They were characterized by their use of visible brushstrokes and their focus on capturing the changing effects of light.
The art of creating three-dimensional forms, either by carving or modeling materials such as stone, metal, or clay.
A type of fast-drying paint made of pigment suspended in acrylic polymer emulsion.
A style of art, architecture, and music characterized by elaborate ornamentation, curved forms, and dramatic contrasts of light and shadow.
The art of decorative handwriting, often using a pen or brush to create stylized lettering and ornamental designs.
An artistic movement that emerged in Europe during World War I, characterized by a rejection of traditional values and a focus on absurdity, irony, and irrationality.
The art of cutting or incising a design into a hard surface, such as metal or wood, to create a printed image.
An early 20th-century art movement characterized by its use of bright colors, bold brushstrokes, and simplified forms.
Writing or drawings scribbled, scratched, or sprayed illicitly on a wall or other surface in a public place.
A color or shade, often used to refer to the dominant color in a painting or work of art.
A work of art created by arranging objects, materials, or other elements in a specific location or environment.
A large painting or other artwork applied directly to a wall, ceiling, or other large surface.
The art or practice of taking and processing photographs.
(two word)An art movement that emerged in the 1950s and 1960s, characterized by the use of popular images and cultural artifacts in art, often with a sense of irony or commentary.
An artistic and literary movement that sought to represent the world as it really is, without idealization or stylization.
An artistic and literary movement that sought to explore the workings of the subconscious mind, often characterized by dreamlike or fantastical imagery.
A type of paint made from a water-soluble pigment, often used for delicate or transparent effects in painting.
A type of printmaking technique in which a design is carved into a block of wood, which is then inked and printed onto paper or other materials.
The process or result of distilling the essential qualities of something into a simplified or abstract form, often used in reference to art.
(two words)An art form that involves the creation of a live performance or event, often incorporating elements of theater, dance, and music.
An artistic and architectural movement that emerged in the 18th century, characterized by a return to the principles and forms of classical Greek and Roman art.

celebration.definition: The date on which an event took place in a previous year.
Inflatable decorations, often made of rubber or latex and filled with air or helium.
A long strip of cloth or paper with a message or design, often hung up as a decoration.
A sweet baked dessert often served at celebrations, typically made of flour, sugar, and eggs.
A cylindrical piece of wax with a wick in the middle, used for giving light, especially during celebrations.
A type of sparkling wine made from grapes grown in the Champagne region of France.
Small pieces of brightly colored paper or plastic, often thrown during celebrations.
Items used to adorn or beautify a space for a special occasion or celebration.
Explosive devices that produce colorful displays of light and sound, often used to celebrate holidays or special occasions.
The reproductive structure of flowering plants, often used as decoration for special occasions.
Something given to someone as a present, especially on a special occasion such as a birthday or holiday.
A day of celebration or commemoration, typically recognized by law or tradition.
A written or verbal request inviting someone to go somewhere or to do something, especially to attend a special event.
A form of artistic expression that uses sound and rhythm to convey emotion and meaning, often played at celebrations.
A procession of people or vehicles, often to celebrate a special occasion or event.
A social gathering of people for a celebration or other festive occasion.
Another word for 'gifts', something given to someone as a present, especially on a special occasion.
Long, narrow strips of colored paper or plastic, often hung up as a decoration for celebrations.
An unexpected or astonishing event or situation, often used to create excitement or joy during celebrations.
A ritual in which people raise their glasses and drink to honor or celebrate someone or something.
A long-established custom or belief that is passed down from generation to generation, often associated with celebrations.
Delicious snacks or sweets, often served at celebrations.
A ceremony in which two people are united in marriage, often celebrated with a reception or party.

cinema.definition: a person who performs in plays, movies, or television shows
the person who controls the making of a film and supervises the actors, camera crew, and other staff
the script or written text of a movie, including dialogue and descriptions of characters and sets
the art and technique of film photography, including camera movement, framing, lighting, and other visual effects
a movie or book that continues the story or characters from a previous one
a movie or book that tells the story that happened before a previous one
the main bad character in a movie, novel, or play
the main good character in a movie, novel, or play
the music or songs that appear in a movie, often released as a separate album
the technique of creating the illusion of motion and change by rapidly displaying a sequence of static images that minimally differ from each other
an annual American awards ceremony honoring outstanding achievements in the movie industry
a movie or other entertainment product that is very successful and makes a lot of money
computer-generated imagery, the use of computer graphics to create or enhance visual elements in movies and other media
a new version of a movie, TV show, or other entertainment property, with a new cast, crew, or storyline
a romantic comedy movie, a movie that combines elements of romance and comedy
a group of three related novels, movies, or other works
a piece of information about the plot or ending of a movie or book that may spoil the surprise or suspense for viewers or readers
a genre of fiction, often in the form of a detective story, that involves a puzzle or crime to be solved

science fiction, a genre of speculative fiction that deals with imaginative and futuristic concepts such as advanced science and technology, space exploration, time travel, parallel universes, and extraterrestrial life
a genre of fiction that is intended to frighten, scare, or disgust the audience
a genre of fiction that combines elements of mystery, suspense, and horror
a genre of fiction that focuses on physical challenges and feats of daring, often involving violence
a genre of fiction that is intended to make the audience laugh
a genre of fiction that is intended to be serious and to convey a message or lesson
a genre of fiction that focuses on love and relationships
a genre of fiction that involves exciting and dangerous events
a genre of fiction that involves magic, supernatural forces, or other elements that are not realistic
a nonfiction book or movie that tells the story of a person's life
a nonfiction book or movie that tells the story of a person's life, written by that person
a nonfiction book or movie that tells the story of a person's life, written by that person
a nonfiction movie or TV show that tells a story about real people or events
a nonfiction book or movie that tells the story of a person's life, written by that person
a book or movie that tells a true story about real people or events
a book or movie that tells a story about imaginary people or events

city.definition: A condition; a set of circumstances applying at any given time.
A large settlement, bigger than a town; sometimes with a specific legal definition, depending on the place.
(physical) An area; somewhere within an area.
A measure of the extent of a surface; it is measured in square units.
To bowl a yorker at a batsman, especially to get a batsman out in this way.
An administrative division of an area.
The land ruled by a count or a countess.
A settlement; an area with residential districts, shops and amenities, and its own local government; especially one larger than a village and smaller than a city.
A rural habitation of size between a hamlet and a town.
A group sharing a common understanding, and often the same language, law, manners, and/or tradition.
A paved part of road, usually in a village or a town.
A stopping place.
A region of the earth or of a continent; a district or country.
Already-produced durable goods available for use as a factor of production, such as steam shovels (equipment) and office buildings (structures).
An act of transporting; conveyance.
The chief executive of the municipal government of a city, borough, &c., formerly usually appointed as a caretaker by European royal courts but now usually appointed or elected locally.
A district with a government that typically encloses no other governed districts; a borough, city, or incorporated town or village.
A place on the coast at which ships can shelter, or dock to load and unload cargo or passengers.
Related to the (or any) city.
A financial instrument issued by a municipality.
An airfield (an area designated for the takeoff and landing of aircraft), including one or more runways and (for commercial airports) one or more passenger terminals.
To encircle something or simultaneously extend in all directions.
A bishop empowered to oversee other bishops; an archbishop.
A business partnership; the name under which it trades.
An underground railway.
The territory of a town.
The main business part of a city or town, usually located at or near its center.
A fortified town.
The quality of being a neighbor, of living nearby, next to each-other; proximity.

A residential area located on the outskirts of a city or large town that usually includes businesses that cater to its residents; such as schools, grocery stores, shopping centers, restaurants, convenience stores, etc.
An organized culture encompassing many communities, often on the scale of a nation or a people; a stage or system of social, political or technical development.
Relating to a mayor (or the office of the mayor).
Throughout a city.
A Greek city-state.
The visual elements of a street, including the road, adjoining buildings, sidewalks, street furniture, trees and open spaces, etc, that combine to form the street's character.
A continuous aggregation of built-up urban communities created as a result of urban sprawl.
A large conurbation, where two or more large cities have sprawled outward to meet, forming something larger than a metropolis; a megacity.
An area of undeveloped landscape, such as park land left within a city during planning and zoning other areas for development.

An urban or other populated area containing a high density of buildings constructed of concrete or similar materials, especially one which lacks greenery and which seems unattractive, harsh, or unsafe.
(chiefly British) An area of land; a district, region.
A set of draught animals, such as two horses in front of a carriage.
A dark image projected onto a surface where light (or other radiation) is blocked by the shade of an object.
A gathering of people for the purchase and sale of merchandise at a set time, often periodic.
A governmental unit created on land of another country owned by colonists from a country.

Any considerable and connected part of a space or surface; specifically, a tract of land or sea of considerable but indefinite extent; a country; a district; in a broad sense, a place without special reference to location or extent but viewed as an entity for geographical, social or cultural reasons.
A motor vehicle for transporting large numbers of people along roads.
A person from the countryside; a rustic.
A civil force granted the legal authority for law enforcement and maintaining public order.

family.definition: Used as plural of person; a body of human beings considered generally or collectively; a group of two or more persons.
A group of people who are closely related to one another (by blood, marriage or adoption); kin; for example, a set of parents and their children; an immediate family.
An advertisement by which individuals attempt to meet others with similar interests.
A dwelling.
A structure built or serving as an abode of human beings.
One's male offspring.
A person who has not yet reached adulthood, whether natural (puberty), cultural (initiation), or legal (majority)
A (generally human) male who begets a child.
A married woman, especially in relation to her spouse.
Strong affection.
A (human) female who has given birth to a baby
One's female offspring.
Son of the same parents as another person.
A person who has not yet reached adulthood, whether natural (puberty), cultural (initiation), or legal (majority)
A daughter of the same parents as another person; a female sibling.
A person other than a family member, spouse or lover whose company one enjoys and towards whom one feels affection.
The master of a house; the head of a family; a householder.
Connection or association; the condition of being related.
A person in a marriage or marital relationship.
The state of being married.
Two partners in a romantic or sexual relationship.
One of the two persons from whom one is immediately biologically descended; a mother or father.
To give part of what one has to somebody else to use or consume.
A taxonomic category ranking between a family and a genus; formerly called a tribe
A unit of people consisting of family members, distant or immediate.
A grouping of smaller peoples or tribes as a nation.
Collectively, all the persons who live in a given house; a family including attendants, servants etc.; a domestic or family establishment.
A socially, ethnically, or politically cohesive group of people.
Someone in the same family; someone connected by blood, marriage, or adoption.
The brother or brother-in-law of one’s parent.
A father of someone's parent.
The child of a person's uncle or aunt; a first cousin.
A mother of someone's parent.
The sister or sister-in-law of one's parent.
A daughter of one's sibling, brother-in-law, or sister-in-law; either a daughter of one's brother (fraternal niece) or a daughter of one's sister (sororal niece).
A daughter of one's child.
The youngest child in a family, or individual in a group.
The eldest child in a family, or individual in a group.
A son of one's child.
A son of one's sibling, brother-in-law, or sister-in-law; either a son of one's brother (fraternal nephew) or a son of one's sister (sororal nephew).
A company of people that share the same interest or aim.
(usually transitive, sometimes intransitive, stative) To have a strong affection for (someone or something).
A group of people all descended from a common ancestor, in fact or belief.
The sister or sister-in-law of one’s parent.
A mother of someone's parent.
A father, a male parent.
The daughter of someone's child.
(familiar) mother.
Descent in a line from a common progenitor; progeny; descending line of offspring or ascending line of parentage.
A daughter of one’s sibling, brother-in-law, or sister-in-law; either the daughter of one's brother ("fraternal niece"), or of one's sister ("sororal niece").
One from whom a person is descended, whether on the father's or mother's side, at any distance of time; a progenitor; a forefather.
A person living on adjacent or nearby land; a person situated adjacently or nearby; anything (of the same type of thing as the subject) in an adjacent or nearby position.
Race; family; breed; kind.
A person who shares a parent; one's brother or sister who one shares a parent with.
The husband of one's biological mother, other than one's biological father, especially following the divorce or death of the father.
Relation or connection by blood, marriage or adoption
The wife of one's biological father, other than one's biological mother.
Grandmother
Having kinship or relationship; related by same-bloodedness; having affinity; being akin; kindred.
A family consisting of parents and children, along with either grandparents, grandchildren, aunts or uncles, cousins, etc.
The son of one's spouse, but not one's own child.
The area of private law pertaining to family matters and domestic relations.
The daughter of one's spouse and not of oneself.
To be, or act as, a grandfather to.
A family unit consisting of two parents (traditionally a mother and a father) and their children.
The daughter of one's stepparent who is not the daughter of either of one's parents.
The son of one's stepparent who is not the son of either of one's biological parents.
A consanguineous or family relationship through parentage or descent. A blood relationship.
A sister of grandparent
A person considered alone, rather than as belonging to a group of people.
To cause someone to become less of a father.
Something given to another voluntarily, without charge.
Someone who is associated with another in a common activity or interest.
A very young human, particularly from birth to a couple of years old or until walking is fully mastered.
A partially specified but unnamed person.
(sometimes attributive) Something which supports.
Son of the same parents as another person.

fauna.definition: The state of organisms preceding their death, characterized by biological processes such as metabolism and reproduction and distinguishing them from inanimate objects; the state of being alive and living.
The undomesticated state of a wild animal
A cold-blooded vertebrate animal that lives in water, moving with the help of fins and breathing with gills.

In scientific usage, a multicellular organism that is usually mobile, whose cells are not encased in a rigid cell wall (distinguishing it from plants and fungi) and which derives energy solely from the consumption of other organisms (distinguishing it from plants).
A fully grown human or animal.
A member of the class of animals Aves in the phylum Chordata, characterized by being warm-blooded, having feathers and wings usually capable of flight, and laying eggs.
Plants considered as a group, especially those of a particular country, region, time, etc.
Conditions suitable for an organism or population of organisms to live.
A member of the class of animals Aves in the phylum Chordata, characterized by being warm-blooded, having feathers and wings usually capable of flight, and laying eggs.
Animals, plants, and fungi, not normally domesticated, often to the exclusion of plants, fungi, fish, insects and other invertebrates, and microscopic plants and animals; hence:
The branch of biology dealing with the relationships of organisms with their environment and with each other.
Any animal other than a human; usually only applied to land vertebrates, especially large or dangerous four-footed ones.
The diversity (number and variety of species) of plant and animal life within a region.
An unsettled and uncultivated tract of land in its natural state; a barren land; a wild or waste.
Plants, taken collectively.
The part of biology relating to the animal kingdom, including the structure, embryology, evolution, classification, habits, and distribution of all animals, both living and extinct.
A living being; an animal or (sometimes derogatory) a human.
Study of the forms of life existing in prehistoric or geologic times, especially as represented by fossils.
A system formed by an ecological community and its environment that functions as a unit.
Relating to the science or research of archaeology.
An area of land managed to conserve wildlife or plant habitat or other natural features.
A discrete and complete living thing, such as animal, plant, fungus or microorganism.
The birds (e.g. of an area) collectively.
An animal of the Amphibia; any four-legged vertebrate that does not have amniotic eggs, living both on land and in water.
A forest in a climate with high annual rainfall and no dry season.
An animal without vertebrae, i.e. backbone.
A system formed by an ecological community and its environment that functions as a unit.
The living organisms of a region.
Any plant that produces flowers and fruit; an angiosperm.
A chain or range of rocks, sand, or coral lying at or near the surface of the water.
An animal without vertebrae, i.e. backbone.
Any of a group of some twenty thousand species of vascular plants classified in the division Pteridophyta that lack seeds and reproduce by shedding spores to initiate an alternation of generations.
An amphibian, a kind of frog (order Anura) with shorter hindlegs and a drier, wartier skin, many in family Bufonidae.
To make (an animal) tame; to domesticate.
The process of assembling or bringing together.
A person who studies or practices ornithology.
An animal seen as being without human reason; a senseless beast.
A reef formed by compacted coral skeletons
Any of the predatory amphibious reptiles of the family Crocodylidae; a crocodilian, any species of the order Crocodilia, which also includes the alligators, caimans and gavials.
A marsh of saline water, found in the intertidal zone between land and sea, characterized by halophytic plants such as grasses and sedges adapted to periodic flooding with salt water.
Any member of the family Cactaceae, a family of flowering New World succulent plants suited to a hot, semi-desert climate.
Free-floating small protozoa, crustaceans (such as krill), etc. and the eggs and larvae from larger animals.
A woodland creature with pointed ears, legs, and short horns of a goat and a fondness for unrestrained revelry.
A bird having a melodious song or call.
An organism that feeds chiefly on plants; an animal that feeds on herbage or vegetation as the main part of its diet.

Any of various land-dwelling reptiles, of the family Testudinidae or the order Testudines , whose body is enclosed in a shell (carapace plus plastron). The animal can withdraw its head and four legs partially into the shell, providing some protection from predators.
A member of the phylum Chordata; numerous animals having a notochord at some stage of their development; in vertebrates this develops into the spine
The birds, or all the kinds of birds, inhabiting a region.
(usually affectionate) A creature, an animal.
(usually affectionate) A creature, an animal.
Any bird that inhabits a freshwater environment.
An animal which is able to consume both plants (like a herbivore) and meat (like a carnivore).
Any animal that undergoes development from an embryo stage with three tissue layers, namely the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
An animal or plant that has been domesticated.
An occurrence of a disease or disorder in a population of non-human animals at a frequency higher than that expected in a given time period. Compare epidemic.
A pestering animal such as one that kills or harasses a farmer's livestock or crops.
A cold-blooded animal
Any of the class Mammalia, a class of warm-blooded vertebrates having hair, a mammary gland, and usually a four-chambered heart.
An animal having a backbone or spinal column.
An animal that feeds on plants.
An animal that feeds on other animals.
An animal that feeds on insects.
An animal that feeds on both plants and animals.
An animal that hunts and kills other animals for food.
An animal that is hunted and killed by another for food.

finance.definition: A short circuit.
The body with the power to make and/or enforce laws to control a country, land area, people or organization.
A specific commercial enterprise or establishment.
Already-produced durable goods available for use as a factor of production, such as steam shovels (equipment) and office buildings (structures).
A soldier of the lowest rank in the army.
Administration; the use of limited resources combined with forecasting, planning, leadership and execution skills to achieve predetermined specific goals.
Pertaining to an economy.
A person who is trained to preach, to perform religious ceremonies, and to afford pastoral care at a Protestant church.
A chief officer or administrator, especially one who can make significant decisions on their own authority.
A legally or socially binding conceptual contract of entitlement to wealth, void of intrinsic value, payable for all debts and taxes, and regulated in supply.
An institution where one can place and borrow money and take care of financial affairs.
Related to finances.
A bad habit.
Effective management of a community or system, or especially its resources.
To design (a building, machine, etc.).
One appointed as the substitute of another, and empowered to act for them, in their name or their behalf; a substitute in office
The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of livestock
A store or supply.
The management of money and other assets.
A sum or source of money.
The amount of money or resources earmarked for a particular institution, activity or time-frame.
An act or instance of lending, an act or instance of granting something for temporary use.
The exchange or buying and selling of commodities; especially the exchange of merchandise, on a large scale, between different places or communities; extended trade or traffic.
Section
The act of investing, or state of being invested.
Reliance on the truth of something said or done; faith; trust.
Money paid to the government other than for transaction-specific goods and services.
A bond issued by a corporation.
To pay for.
Money in the form of notes/bills and coins, as opposed to cheques/checks or electronic transactions.
To make (products or services) available for sale and promote them.
A means of indemnity against a future occurrence of an uncertain event.
Property that cannot easily be moved, usually buildings and the ground they are built on.
An action, state of mind, or object one has an obligation to perform for another, adopt toward another, or give to another.
To deal with a bank or financial institution, or for an institution to provide financial services to a client.
A public official in certain countries having control of public revenue.
The government official in charge of the Treasury.
A place where treasure is stored safely.
Fairness, impartiality, or justice as determined in light of "natural law" or "natural right".
To provide explanation.
A case for carrying papers, drawings, photographs, maps and other flat documents.
To conduct, or procure money for, financial operations; manage finances.
Of, pertaining to, or consisting of money.
One who conducts the business of banking; one who, individually, or as a member of a company, keeps an establishment for the deposit or loan of money, or for traffic in money, bills of exchange, etc.
The act of imposing taxes and the fact of being taxed.
Something or someone of any value; any portion of one's property or effects so considered.
To conduct, or procure money for, financial operations; manage finances.
To spend money, time, or energy on something, especially for some benefit or purpose; used with in.
Money invested in an innovative enterprise in which both the potential for profit and the risk of loss are considerable.
To pay back.
The act of repaying.
To construct or draw up a budget.
Finance that is provided to unemployed or low-income people or groups
The act of repaying.
To write below or under; subscribe.
A roll of banknotes or other paper currency, carried in lieu of a wallet.
To renew the terms of a loan.
The way that a corporation finances its assets through some combination of equity, debt, and hybrid securities.
Direct payment by cash, as opposed to through a bank.
Technology
To seek the opinion or advice of another; to take counsel; to deliberate together; to confer.
(chiefly dialectal) To gather.
A secret supporter or follower.
Something which is bought; a purchase.
To engage in trade.
The body of binding rules and regulations, customs and standards established in a community by its legislative and judicial authorities.
The legal department of a company.
A commodity; see realty.

food.definition: In good health.

A substance (of molecular formula H₂O) found at room temperature and pressure as a clear liquid; it is present naturally as rain, and found in rivers, lakes and seas; its solid form is ice and its gaseous form is steam.
The act of forming, causing, or constituting; workmanship; construction.
An organism that is not an animal, especially an organism capable of photosynthesis. Typically a small or herbaceous organism of this kind, rather than a tree.
The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of livestock

In scientific usage, a multicellular organism that is usually mobile, whose cells are not encased in a rigid cell wall (distinguishing it from plants and fungi) and which derives energy solely from the consumption of other organisms (distinguishing it from plants).
Cereal plants, Oryza sativa of the grass family whose seeds are used as food.
An eating establishment in which diners are served food, usually by waiters at their tables but sometimes (as in a fast food restaurant) at a counter.
(often in the plural) In general, a product of plant growth useful to man or animals.
Food given to (especially herbivorous) animals.
Something to be eaten; a meal; a food item.
To consume (a liquid) through the mouth.
Any of numerous large, complex naturally-produced molecules composed of one or more long chains of amino acids, in which the amino acid groups are held together by peptide bonds.
A midday meal (in a context in which the evening meal is called supper or tea).

A white liquid produced by the mammary glands of female mammals to nourish their young. From certain animals, especially cows, it is also called dairy milk and is a common food for humans as a beverage or used to produce various dairy products such as butter, cheese, and yogurt.
The flesh (muscle tissue) of an animal used as food.
A domestic fowl, Gallus gallus, especially when young.
To prepare (food) for eating by heating it, often by combining it with other ingredients.
Farm animals; animals domesticated for cultivation.
A going; journey; travel; voyage; course; passage.
Cured meat from the sides, belly or back of a pig.
A dairy product made from curdled or cultured milk.
The organic process by which an organism assimilates food and uses it for growth and maintenance.
Affected by hunger; desiring of food; having a physical need for food.
A need or compelling desire for food.
A yellowish citrus fruit.
Food that is prepared and eaten, usually at a specific time, and usually in a comparatively large quantity (as opposed to a snack).
The meat from a cow, bull or other bovine.
Any plant.
Any of various dishes commonly made by combining liquids, such as water or stock with other ingredients, such as meat and vegetables, that contribute flavor and texture.
A baked Italian dish of a thinly rolled bread dough crust typically topped before baking with tomato sauce, cheese and other ingredients such as meat, vegetables or fruit
Anything edible.
Corn; a type of grain of the species Zea mays.
A liquid to consume; a drink, such as tea, coffee, liquor, beer, milk, juice, or soft drinks, usually excluding water.
Fish, shellfish, seaweed, and other edible aquatic life.
Food that is served quickly, often standardized and pre-prepared.
A light meal.
A type of grass (such as wheat, rice or oats) cultivated for its edible grains.
A person who does not eat animal flesh, or, in some cases, use any animal products.
A source of nourishment, such as food, that can be metabolized by an organism to give energy and build tissue.
Dough made from wheat and water and sometimes mixed with egg and formed into various shapes; often sold in dried form and typically boiled for eating.
To restore to health.
A Japanese dish made of small portions of sticky white rice flavored with vinegar, usually wrapped in seaweed and filled or topped with fish, vegetables or meat.
A small room, closet, or cabinet usually located in or near the kitchen, dedicated to shelf-stable food storage and/or storing kitchenware, like a larder, but smaller.
A milk-based product stiffened by a bacterium-aided curdling process, and sometimes mixed with fruit or other flavoring.
To preserve food (or sometimes other things) in a salt, sugar or vinegar solution.
Something that provides support or nourishment.
A member of a group of people who live by hunting animals and gathering edible plants for their main food sources, and who do not keep animals or farm land.
The act of nourishing or the state of being nourished
Food fit for human consumption.
A material that may be used as food.
Food.
A food or meal that needs little preparation or cooking, especially one sold prepackaged.
Food, especially for livestock.
A formula for preparing or using a medicine; a prescription; also, a medicine prepared from such instructions.
A machine outfitted with sharp blades, for mashing, crushing or liquefying food ingredients.
Food or fodder, particularly that taken in by plants or animals.
An act of being of assistance to someone.
Any of a class of organic compounds (such as ethanol) containing a hydroxyl functional group (-OH).
A solid, more or less rigid object of metal or wood with a uniform cross-section smaller than its length.
The act of traveling; passage from place to place.

A substance that is flowing, and keeping no shape, such as water; a substance of which the molecules, while not tending to separate from one another like those of a gas, readily change their relative position, and which therefore retains no definite shape, except that determined by the containing receptacle; an inelastic fluid.
Any activity designed to develop or hone a skill or ability.
Merchandise
Excess of material, useless by-products or damaged, unsaleable products; garbage; rubbish.
Food, especially convenience snack foods.
To provide, particularly:

health.definition: To make (something) better; to increase the value or productivity (of something).
The process of imparting knowledge, skill and judgment.
Diligent inquiry or examination to seek or revise facts, principles, theories, applications, etc.; laborious or continued search after truth.
A set of structured activities.
